questions.text: In surgical stress all hormone is increased except: (PG1 May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is ADH and it increases during surgical stress because of activation of RAAS system Option B pituitary during stress secretes ACTH, which in turn initiates sudden increase in cortisol level. questions.text: Early stage of trauma is characterized by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) METABOLIC AND NEUROENDOCRINE RESPONSE TO TRAUMA OR SURGERY • Injury Phase (Phase of catabolism): Begins at the time of injury and lasts for 2-5 days Phase of hypermetabolism: Stress hormones (cortisol, catecholamines and glucagon) and volume control hormones (renin-angiotensin, aldosterone and ADH) are increased. This leads to proteolysis, lipolysis, hyperglycemia and wound healing despite of negative nitrogen balance. • Turning Point: Transient period marked physiologically by turning off of the neuroendocrine response and clinically by the appearance of getting well. • Early Anabolic Phase: Marked by gain in muscular strength or positive nitrogen balance. • Late Anabolic Phase: Marked by gain in weight and body fat or positive caloric balance.

questions.text: In case of clearing airway one of the following is not included: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In case of clearing airway we do not include head lift, infact while clearing airway what we have is head goes back and down. Chin lift, neck tilt and mouth gag are definitive steps of clearing airway.

questions.text: FAST stands for (AIIMS Nov 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) FAST stands for Focused assessment sonogram for trauma. FAST is basically the USG done in casualty and it is the first test to which any patient of blunt abdominal trauma is subjected. The main aim of doing FAST is to look for any intra peritoneal fluid collection. In FAST we keep probe at epigastric, right hypochondriac, left hypochondriac and suprapubic region and by this we get an idea about fluid collection in peritoneal cavity and pericardial cavity. Now a days we perform eFAST, in this we keep probe in right and left lung fields to look for pneumothorax and pleural effusion also.

questions.text: Damage control surgery is: (AIIMS May 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) DCS is based on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. Damage control includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen in an effort to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage. These patients are often at limits of their physiological reserve when they present to operating room and persistent operative efforts result in exacerbation of their underlying hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis, initiating a vicious cycle that culminates in death. In these situations, abrupt termination of the procedure after control of surgical hemorrhage and contamination, followed by ICU resuscitation and staged reconstruction, can be life saving.

questions.text: Aims of abbreviated laparotomy: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In damage control surgery we just perform a staged laparotomy to control some acute insult or pathology like a bleeder in the abdomen or hemorrhage from liver or spleen or some intra abdominal contamination caused by a perforated viscera.

questions.text: Severely injured patient presents with spinal fracture and unconsciousness. First thing to be done is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-GCS scoring is done for disability.it is checked after ABC steps. Option B-spinal stabilization by cervical collar is very important but airway maintenance is the first priority. Option C-mannitol drip is usually avoided because it`s a diuretic and patient may already be hypotensive due to blood loss in RTAs. Option D-Concept behind ATLS is save the life (i.e. prevent an impending cardiac arrest) by addressing the most dangerous threat to life first.We follow ABCDE approach that is airway maintenance,breathing,circulation,disability,exposure.Hence airway maintenance should be the answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of massive transfusion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Massive transfusion (typically defined as replacing a patient's total blood volume within 24 hours or transfusing more than 10 units of packed red blood cells) can lead to several metabolic complications due to the preservatives and additives in stored blood products. Complications include: Hypocalcemia Due to citrate in stored blood binding calcium. Hypomagnesemia Can occur similarly due to citrate binding magnesium. Hyperkalemia Stored red blood cells leak potassium over time, especially in older units. When transfused rapidly, this can cause elevated serum potassium levels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male in the emergency room requires rapid fluid resuscitation due to hypovolemic shock. Which of the following intravenous cannula gauges is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 18G For rapid fluid resuscitation, a larger cannula gauge with a smaller number (e.g., 18G or 16G) is preferred, as it allows a higher flow rate. Smaller gauges like 22G or 24G are suitable for slower infusions or pediatric use, but they are not ideal for high-volume fluid administration. • 18G cannula (Green): Commonly used for rapid fluid and blood product administration. • 20G cannula ( Pink) : Suitable for routine IV infusions. • 22G and 24G cannulas (Blue and Yellow): Used for smaller veins or in pediatric patients.

questions.text: What is the approximate flow rate of fluids through a 20G intravenous cann ula under normal conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 60-80 mL/min The flow rate of fluids through an IV cannula depends on its gauge size, with smaller gauges (larger numbers) having lower flow rates. Approximate flow rates are: • 18G: ~105 mL/min • 20G: ~60-80 mL/min • 22G: ~35 mL/min • 24G: ~20 mL/min

questions.text: A 25-year-old male involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision is brought to the emergency department with suspected spinal trauma. During the primary survey, the log roll maneuver is performed. Which of the following is the primary purpose of the log roll method in trauma management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) To check for spinal tenderness and examine the posterior surface The log roll method is a controlled maneuver used in trauma patients with suspected spinal injuries to safely turn the patient while maintaining spinal alignment. • Purpose: To assess for spinal tenderness, deformities, open wounds, or signs of injury on the posterior surface. • The maneuver requires at least 3-4 team members: o One stabilizing the head and neck to maintain spinal alignment. o Two or more assisting in rolling the patient. • It is typically performed during the secondary survey in trauma assessment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with severe trauma is receiving a massive blood transfusion. Which of the following is a key component of the massive transfusion protocol (MTP)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1:1:1 ratio of packed red blood cells (PRBCs), plasma, and platelets Massive transfusion protocols aim to restore blood volume, oxygen-carrying capacity, and coagulation factors to prevent complications such as coagulopathy, acidosis, and hypothermia. • A 1:1:1 ratio (PRBCs, plasma, and platelets) mimics whole blood and optimizes hemostasis. • Tranexamic acid is often used early in massive transfusions to reduce fibrinolysis. • Isolated PRBC administration can lead to dilutional coagulopathy and worsened outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common complication of massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above Complications of massive blood transfusion include: • Hyperkalemia: Due to potassium leakage from stored RBCs. • Hypocalcemia: Caused by citrate in blood products binding to calcium. • Hypothermia: Results from transfusion of cold blood products. Close monitoring and appropriate interventions (e.g., calcium gluconate, warming devices) are essential.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a pneumothorax requiring chest tube insertion. The appropriate site for tube placement is the "triangle of safety." Which of the following structures define the boundaries of this triangle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterior border of pectoralis major, lateral border of latissimus dorsi, and a line superior to the nipple The triangle of safety is a key anatomical landmark for chest tube insertion to ensure proper placement and avoid injury to vital structures. The boundaries of the triangle are: 1. Anterior boundary: Lateral border of pectoralis major 2. Posterior boundary: Lateral border of latissimus dorsi 3. Inferior boundary: A horizontal line at the level of the 5th intercostal space (just above the nipple line in males) 4. Base: The axilla The triangle of safety provides a safe zone for thoracostomy, minimizing the risk of injury to the diaphragm, internal organs, or major blood vessels.

questions.text: A patient with a large pneumothorax requires chest tube placement. Which intercostal space is most commonly targeted within the triangle of safety?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 5th The 5th intercostal space within the triangle of safety is the most common site for chest tube insertion. This level is usually located at the mid-axillary line, just above the nipple line in males. It provides optimal access to the pleural cavity while avoiding injury to critical structures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. He has signs of hemorrhagic shock (blood pressure: 70/40 mmHg, heart rate: 130 bpm) and a distended abdomen. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) reveals free fluid in the abdomen. He is taken to the operating room for damage control surgery (DCS). Which of the following is NOT a component of DCS?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Definitive repair of all injuries Damage control surgery (DCS) is a staged approach aimed at controlling life-threatening conditions in critically injured patients. The components include: 1. Hemorrhage control – This involves stopping active bleeding using methods like packing, vessel ligation, or other temporary hemostatic techniques. 2. Prevention of contamination – This typically involves closing perforated hollow viscera or temporarily diverting bowel contents. 3. Temporary abdominal closure – The abdomen is often left open to reduce intra-abdominal pressure and allow for re-exploration. Definitive repair of all injuries is NOT part of the initial DCS phase because the focus is on stabilizing the patient physiologically (e.g., managing hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy) before proceeding with definitive repairs in subsequent operations. This approach minimizes operative time and allows for better patient outcomes in critically unstable trauma patients.
